STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER
LANS ING
ROBERT GORDON
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
July 21, 2020
Kathleen Sperling
Arenac County DHHS
3709 Deep River Road
Standish, MI 48658
RE: License #: CP060200953
Arenac County DHHS
3709 Deep River Road
Standish, MI 48658
Dear Ms. Sperling:
Attached is the Interim Report for the above referenced facility completed on July 15 - 20,
2020. Due to the violations a written corrective action plan is required. It should be noted
that violations of any licensing rules are also violations of the ISEP and your contract.
The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
licensing statute and rule or section of the contract or ISEP citation.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager, Courtney Atkins at (517) 599-3667.
Sincerely,
P.O. BOX 30650 • LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov • (517) 335-1980

Barbara Cote, Licensing Consultant WOC
MDHHS\Division of Child Welfare Licensing
Suite 11
701 S. Elmwood
Traverse City, MI 49684
enclosure
Shelly Marner, BSC 2 Director
2

MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING
INTERIM INSPECTION REPORT

Licensee Name: Michigan Department of Health and Human
Services

Lansing, MI 48902

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
1.) The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules except
for the following:
R 400.12417 Foster parent information.
(1) An agency shall provide a foster parent with all of the
following information before the placement or replacement of a
child:
(a) Child's name.
(b) Child’s date of birth.
(c) Available known information about the child’s health.
(d) Any known history of abuse or neglect of the child.
(e) All known emotional and psychological factors relating to
the care of the child.
(f) All known behavioral problems of the child.
(g) Circumstances necessitating placement or replacement
of the child.
(h) Any other known information to enable the foster parent
to provide a stable, safe, and healthy environment for the
foster child and the foster family, including information about
siblings who do not reside in the foster home.
(i) Name of assigned social service worker.
One of three open foster care case files reviewed lacked documentation that the
foster parent was provided with the information required in subsections (a) through
(i).
R 400.12502 Program statement.
(2) An agency shall give a copy of the program statement to a
youth before placement in independent living.
One of one independent living case files reviewed lacked documentation that the
agency provided the program statement as required.
R 400.12503 Policy and procedures.
(3) An agency shall provide a youth in independent living with a
copy of the agency’s policies and procedures required by this
rule.
3

One of one independent living case files reviewed lacked documentation that the
agency provided the policies and procedures as required.
R 400.12504 Eligibility requirements.
(1) An agency shall document the rationale for selection of
independent living as the most appropriate placement for the
youth.
One of one independent living case files reviewed lacked documentation rationale
for selecting independent living as the most appropriate placement as required.
R 400.12510 Independent living contract.
(1) There shall be a mutually agreed upon contract between the
youth and the agency specifying all of the following:
(a) The responsibilities of the agency and the youth.
(b) A plan for education or work.
(c) An agreement for the youth to meet with the worker at
least one time per calendar month.
(d) The location where the youth is living.
One of one independent living files reviewed lacked an independent living contract
as required.
R 400.12510 Independent living contract.
(2) The agreement shall be signed and dated by the youth and
the social service worker. The contract shall be reviewed and
updated at least once every 90 calendar days and a copy
provided to the youth.
One of one independent living files reviewed lacked the contract every 90-day
calendar days as required.
R 400.12418 Development of service plans.
(2) An agency shall complete written service plans for each
child and parent or parents, as follows:
(b) Within 120 calendar days after the initial removal
and at least once every 90 calendar days thereafter.
One of four open case files reviewed had an updated service plan that was late.
2.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also ISEP violation. Please note that there are
additional ISEP requirements that may not be included in section 1. The facility is in
compliance with all additional ISEP requirements except for the following:
ISEP 6.19 Assessments and Service Plans, Content
(c) Service plans shall be signed by the caseworker, the
caseworker’s supervisor, the parent(s), and the child(ren), if of
4

age to participate. IF the parent(s) or child(ren) or both are not
available or decline to sign the plan, the service plan shall
include an explanation of the steps taken to involve them and
shall identify any follow-up action s to be taken to secure their
participation in services.
Two of four open foster care case files reviewed lacked the required signatures on
the parent agency agreement.
ISEP 6.22 Visits, Worker-Parent
(a)For each child in foster care with a permanency goal of
reunification, the child’s caseworker shall have face-to-face
contacts with the child’s parent(s) as follows:
(1) for the first month the child is in care, two face-to-face
contact with each parent, at least one of which must occur in the
parent’s place of residence.
(2) for each subsequent month, at least one face-to-face contact
with each parent and phone contact as needed, with at least on
contact in each three-month period occurring in the parent’s
place of residence.
One of three open care case files reviewed with a goal of reunification lacked
documentation of monthly contact with the parent as required.
ISEP 6.21 Visits, Worker-Child
(a)Each child in foster care shall be visited by a caseworker at
least two time per month during the child’s first two months of
placement in an initial or new placement, and at least one time
per month thereafter. At least one visit each month shall take
place at the child’s placement location and shall include a
private meeting between the child and the caseworker.
In one of two case files reviewed where a youth was initially placed or replaced, the
file lacked documentation of the caseworker visiting the youth within five days as
required.
3.)Any violation listed in section 1 is also a DHHS Contract violation. Please note that
there are additional DHHS Contract/Policy requirements that may not be included in
section 1. The facility is in compliance will all additional DHHS Contract/Policy
requirements except for the following:
5

FOM 722-08C Foster Care Parent Agency Treatment Plan & Service
Agreement
Signatures
When completed, obtain all signatures as appropriate, including
those of parent(s)/guardian(s), foster care worker, supervisor,
foster parent, caregiver, any youth age 14 and older and in the
case of placement agency foster care cases, the local DHHS
office designee.
One of three open foster care case files reviewed lacked the required caregiver
signatures, which would indicate their involvement in the plan development.
FOM 801 Health Services for Children in Foster Care
Medical Passport requirements.
One of four open case files reviewed lacked the medical passport being completed
as required. The file reviewed was an independent living file and lacked providing the
medical passport upon independent living placement.
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
Technical assistance was provided regarding appropriate documentation of
parenting time visitation as the agency was not coded in MiSACWIS as parenting
time, but as a case contact.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following areas:
No consultation was requested or required.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There was one incident of substantiated child abuse and/or neglect during this
licensing period.
This incident was reviewed and the agency did a thorough assessment, time frames
were met and the agency coordinated with other parties. No concerns were noted.
There were zero incidents of substantiated corporal punishment during this licensing
period.
6

The agency has submitted zero acceptable corrective action plans not related to
maltreatment during this licensing period.
The staff members interviewed reported feeling supported by co-workers as well as
upper management. It was reported that supervisors have an open-door policy and
training opportunities are regularly provided.
VII. DCWL FIELD ANALYST FINDINGS
There were no safety alerts.
VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable licensing
statutes and rules and/or ISEP requirements and/or contract/policy. Upon receipt of an
acceptable corrective action plan, it is recommended that the facility continue on a
regular license.
_______________________________________07/21/2020_
Barbara Cote Date
Licensing Consultant
Approved By:
07/22/2020
________________________________________
Date
Area Manager
